When I was a child in the 1950's, I remember a little boy on our school bus who had some mercury in a bottle.  He was sharing it by pouring a drop about the size of a peanut in the hands of other children.  We rolled it around in our palms and were amazed by it.  I don't remember what happened next.  Probably we gave it back to the little boy who had the bottle for it.  But none of us had any toxic reaction whatsoever.  Vaguely I think we may have taken it home to show our sisters and brothers.  Not sure about this.  Also, my dental fillings were also made from some mercury compound.  I have lived a long life and I still have some of those fillings.  How dangerous is mercury?  However dangerous it is, it is not as dangerous as we are being led to believe.

I would like to submit a correction to this video.

Thiomerosal is rarely, if at all, found in vaccines in this day and age. At the time this video was made, this was also true. Thiomerosal was agreed upon by committee to be reduced and removed from all vaccines in 1999 [1]. As of 2001, Thiomerosal has been removed from all vaccines administered to children in the US [1].

A complete list of Thiomerosal-containing vaccines used in the US can be found at [2]. In influenza vaccines, the amount of mercury is minute. The largest dose of Thiomerosal is 25mcg per vaccine dose of 0.5ml [2]. This may sound like a lot, but that is 0.025mg, or 2.5E-5g. I could not find trials that specifically test the toxicity of thiomerosal, but absorption is minimal compared to this example. Dimethylmercury, the most dangerous and readily absorbed compound of mercury, is deadly at 5mg/kg. Mercury can affect neurons at any concentration, but it appears to cause degeneration around 0.2mg/L (blood concentration) [3,4]. The average human has 5L of blood, so 1mg is meaningfully dangerous. I could not find how much of the mercury in thiomerosal is converted to biosoluble products, but let's assume it's all converted to ethylmercury. At this rate, it would take 400 influenza vaccines to cause harm to a person IF ethylmercury was never excreted from the body. Ethylmercury (EtHg) is FAR less blood soluble than dimethylmercury ((CH3)2Hg) and will be converted to biosoluble products at a significantly lower rate. Additionally, I found the half life of EtHg was about a week, while (CH3)2Hg has a half life of 1.5 months (6 week) [5]. Within 6 weeks, 98.4% of the EtHg is removed from the body. This means that realistically, you would have to get many MANY more vaccines than 400 to build up any dangerous amount of mercury in your body. Keep in mind that the flu shot is yearly, and most humans don't live past 100. To be deadly, a child at 9 pounds (4kg) would need 8,000 flu vaccines to be deadly (within about a month). An adult at 150 pounds (68kg) would need 136,000 vaccinations to be life-threatening. Again, this assumes dimethylmercury is used and not thiomerosal.

Treatment for mercury exposure do exist and have been found in multiple trials to increase mercury excretion through urine at a statistically significant level. 2,3-dimercaptopropanol-sulfonic acid (DMPS) was not found to decrease blood mercury in most trials. However, any mercury excreted from the body obviously reduces mercury content in other areas of the body (such as fat and neuronal tissues) [6]. This assumes a patient does not continue to consume mercury, as DMPS does not contain any of the aforementioned element.

Any reasonable conclusion of my research shows that EVEN IN VACCINES WITH MERCURY, THE AFFECTS ARE LITTLE TO NONE. Again, FEW TO NO vaccines administered today contain ANY mercury. Mercury is dangerous, but vaccines can't harm you with mercury.

Please do not propagate the fear of vaccines. Outdated chemicals that are almost never used pose no risk, but fear of vaccines is currently responsible for the deaths of thousands of people with COVID-19. Also, NONE OF THE VACCINES FOR COVID-19 CONTAIN THIOMEROSAL. How's that for peace of mind?

Common exposures: When most exposures to metallic mercury occur, they occur because mercury is released from a container, or from a product or device that breaks.  If the mercury is not immediately contained or cleaned up, it can evaporate, becoming an invisible, odorless, toxic vapor. "MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEET"
https://fscimage.fishersci.com/msds/96252.htm
Appearance: silver liquid.
Danger! Corrosive. Harmful if inhaled. May be absorbed through intact skin. Causes eye and skin irritation and possible burns. May cause severe respiratory tract irritation with possible burns. May cause severe digestive tract irritation with possible burns. May cause liver and kidney damage. May cause central nervous system effects. This substance has caused adverse reproductive and fetal effects in animals. Inhalation of fumes may cause metal-fume fever. Possible sensitizer.
Target Organs: Blood, kidneys, central nervous system, liver, brain.
Skin: May be absorbed through the skin in harmful amounts. May cause skin sensitization, an allergic reaction, which becomes evident upon re-exposure to this material. Causes skin irritation and possible burns. May cause skin rash (in milder cases), and cold and clammy skin with cyanosis or pale color.
Skin: Get medical aid immediately. Immediately flush skin with plenty of water for at least 15 minutes while removing contaminated clothing and shoes. Wash clothing before reuse. Destroy contaminated shoes.
Handling: Wash thoroughly after handling. Remove contaminated clothing and wash before reuse. Minimize dust generation and accumulation. Keep container tightly closed. Do not get on skin or in eyes. Do not ingest or inhale. Use only in a chemical fume hood. Discard contaminated shoes. Do not breathe vapor.

Your demonstration of amalgamation with gold reminded me of a historical use for mercury I learned about when I visited Sovereign Hill at Ballarat in Victoria: Gold mining, or rather, processing the ore that was dug up. Crush the ore into powder and pass it over a bed of mercury using water. The mercury amalgamates with the gold, leaving the quartz powder to come out the other side. The mercury/gold amalgam is then heated to distil off the mercury for reuse and the gold gets melted down and cast into bars.

Fact: During the 18th and 19th century, Mercury Nitrate was used in the hat-making industry. Workers would use it to turn fur from small animals, such as rabbits and beavers, into felt for hats in a process known as carroting.

The use Mercury Nitrate causes mercury poisoning after being expose to the substance for a long period of time. This causes the workers to have a neurological disorder called Erethism, which is also known as mad hatter disease or mad hatter syndrome. That is where the phrase “mad as a hatter” originated from.

Fun fact! “Gold fever” is actually early mercury poisoning; one of the first symptoms is obsession which is why the miners went crazy for gold. The reason everyone got mercury poisoning was that gold ore was covered in mercury so that it would float in water; it was then sorted through and the mercury burned off. One of the issues with this was that the people who were processing the gold would eat mercury covered gold to steal it and because gold can’t be digested . . . Let’s just say they found it later. The guy whose job it was to burn off the mercury was constantly surrounded by mercury vapor so he dies in five to six years. His children run around the shop, they have six or seven. The guys who ate the gold to steal it had seven or eight but it’s not used anymore except for Alaska and some other places, nowadays people generally use borax. So yeah, mad as a hatter and gold fever are both mercury poisoning, yay!!

Rolled a coin size blob of it on the palm of my right hand in science class at school. The next few  days the area where it touched became itchy and inflamed to the point of being very distressing. As days went by the inflamed area developed hundreds of small blisters that made the itching even worse till they all joined together to be one huge blister filled with fluid. My father got concerned and took me to a Doctor who was mystified how I can be burned without heat. He gave me some ointment to put on it and told me to keep it wrapped till it finally leaked empty on its own and the ointment prevented infection.I used it till all the edges of the blister healed and the skin returned to normal. I avoid mercury like poison today and even old mercury treated photo album paper can give me small clusters of itchy blisters many years later. Not good I must say.

1:30 to go into a bit of detail, there are two forces that molecules exert. These are cohesive and adhesive forces.. Cohesive forces are forces between molecules of the same type and adhesive forces are between one substance and another

Murcury has a high cohesive force, and has less adhesive force. That's why we see Murcury pull in when in a container and not stick to the sides or move around as much!

An opposite example would be water. Water has stronger adhesive forces, but also cohesive forces.. These adhesive forces make it stick to things like glass, and even allows it to travel through sand as it adheres to the granules!

Ancient items were not gold-plated, as electro-plating was not discovered yet. The people took an amalgama of gold and mercury, then heated it, and the gold remained while the mercury evaporated. Ancient clocks were made golden this way (empire pendules, etc.). By this process, one could decide how much yellow to make the gold layer (more gold in the mercury = more yellow tone once burned), and the gold patina was relatively thick compared to modern plating, but this process was extremely dangerous, and workers died often young because of the toxic mercury vapors.

Honestly, only an expert should think of doing anything with mercury, and probably not even then. When I was studying cases in criminal toxicology, I came across one in which two adoptive parents decided to murder their young daughter for insurance money. They decided to feed the child elemental mercury. They added it carefully, in small, unnoticeable doses in her oatmeal and whatever. They were puzzled when the child seemed not to die. They upped the amount and frequency of the doses and ended up feeding her something like two and a half pounds of mercury, to no noticeable effect. The doses were really no longer subtle and a visitor to the house noticed what was going on. The D.A. made out a case of attempted murder, but there was a plea bargain to a charge of assault and battery. The D.A. figured it would be hard to get a jury to convict someone of attempted murder when their method of murder was apparently harmless.

Actually mercury is a very very soft crystal at room temperature.  It forms covalently bonded layers similar to the layers of graphene in graphite.  The layers easily slide over each other giving the crystal the appearance of a liquid.  Its crystal structure is of a sphere.  The sphere has multiple onion-like layers of covalently bonded atoms.  Each layer is one atom thick.  Each layer could be called a giant molecule, the way diamond is a giant molecule.

I used to play with mercury from broken thermometers at home (back in the days they were made of glass) when I was a kid. It is not poisonous like the stupid propaganda today says. As you saw in the video, he submerged his fingers in it and another person did the entire hand. It could get into your body through cuts, so just be careful not to expose open wounds to mercury. Ingesting it is also relatively safe as it will go through your digestive system and come out intact on the other side if you know what I mean. It is not a good idea to do that just because you could have wounds inside your digestive system (ulcers or similar) and then it could get into your blood there. And as you saw, fish doesn’t have plain mercury but a mix of chemicals which is what makes it bad. While it is not a good idea to play with mercury if you don’t know what you are doing, it is NOT as crazy bad as most people think today. And if you saw the video, you saw the part showing gold being devoured by mercury. It is for real, if you have gold rings on your fingers and you play even with a tiny amount of mercury, as soon it touches the gold, it will consume it, the ring will disappear in front of your eyes. Eli Lilly Material Data Safety Sheet for ThimerosalExtracts
Effects of Overexposure:
Topical allergic dermatitis has been reported.Thimerosal contains mercury. Mercury poisoning may occur and topical hypersensitivityreactions may be seen. Early signs of mercury poisoning in adults are nervous system effects,including narrowing of the visual field and numbness in the extremities. Exposure to mercury inutero and in children may cause mild to severe mental retardation and mild to severe motorcoordination impairment. Based on animal data, may be irritating to the eyes.
Reproduction:
Thimerosal - Decreased offspring survival. Mercury - Changes in spermproduction, decreased offspring survival, and offspring nervous system effects including mild tosevere mental retardation and motor coordination impairment.
Chronic Exposure
Thimerosol is a mercuric compound. Toxicity data for thimerosal and mercury are presented.Target Organ Effects: Thimerosal - Kidney effects (tubule necrosis), lung effects (tissuechanges).Mercury - Nervous system effects (insomnia, tremor, anorexia, weakness, headache), liver effects(jaundice, digestive effects (hypermotility, diarrhea).Other Effects: Thimerosal - Decreased weight gain.Reproduction: Thimerosal - Decreased offspring survival.Mercury - Changes in sperm production, decreased offspring survival, and offspring nervoussystemeffects including mild to severe mental retardation and motor coordination impairment.Sensitization: No

Mercury is a very toxic or poisonous substance that people can be exposed to
in several ways. If it is swallowed, like from a broken thermometer, it mostly
passes through your body and very little is absorbed. If you touch it, a small
amount may pass through your skin, but not usually enough to harm you.
Mercury is most harmful when you breathe in the vapors that are released
when a container is open or a spill occurs.

DO NOT TOUCH MERCURY. While Mercury isn't overtly poisonous, even a small drop touching your skin is enough for it to enter your bloodstream, where it is carried to your brain. There it will stay for the rest of your life, slowly building up, your body unable to flush it out. No surgery can remove it, and you will simply have to live with permanent brain damage and potential failure in other parts of the central nervous system. Mercury is also easily vaporized at room temperature, where it can easily be inhaled and absorbed into the body through the lungs.

I appreciate the video you posted here. If there was anything you could add this video, it would be more details about mercury's toxicity (though I'm not sure if that would scare off people too much). It would be useful to clarify why inorganic mercury compounds are more toxic than their counterparts, namely the fact that inorganic mercury is fat soluble which is what facilitates organic mercury's ability to directly access central nervous system for extended periods of time through adjacent fatty tissues. Other facts to mention include the types of toxicity exhibited by mercury compounds, such as their mutagenic, teratogenic, neurotoxic, nephrotoxic, immuno-suppressant, and (probable) carcinogenic properties. The World Heath Organization has a nice web page that sums up the health related issues associated mercury in its various forms and how to mitigate systemic exposure to current and future generations. I'll leave a link here for anyone else interested:

http://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/mercury-and-health

The British Occupational Hygiene Society (BOHS) advises the following actions to be taken in case of a mercury spillage. Mercury is very toxic. Wear gloves. Collect as much mercury as possible using a 5ml or 10ml syringe. Experimentation will be necessary to find the best angle to draw the heavy mercury into the tube. Use a piece of card to gather the droplets together if they are finely divided. Collect any broken glass and other debris into a suitable container. Use card rather than gloved hands if there is broken glass. Small pieces of broken glass which are uncontaminated by mercury are best disposed of in a sharps disposal box. Mercury spill kits are available commercially; they should normally only be used by a competent person.

"strong metallic bonding forces between mercury atoms"

This metal has really weak metallic bonding, that's why it's a liquid, the reason it clumps up in droplets is because it interacts with itself stronger than with surfaces.

Also, never touch mercury................that's just reckless and dumb. It might not absorb through skin, but it will go through small cuts in the skin...cuts which you might not realise you have, it might also sneak in between the crease in between the fingernail and finger...

Also, because of the volatility, it is actaully not a good idea to not wear a mask around mercury. Mad-hatter syndrome is a real thing, sure small doses aren't that bad, but keep in mind mercury is eliminated very (extremely in fact) slowly from the human body.

I cannot verify the accuracy of this, but I have read that cinnabar was at one time used as a red pigment by tattooists. According to the account I read, an army doctor began to notice that a certain group in the military seemed to have an immunity to a common and often fatal venereal disease. On further investigation, he found that virtually all of that group bore tattoos--and among them he further isolated those that had an area of red color in the design. When he identified the source of the pigment, he discovered it contained mercury, and went on to experiment with different mercury compounds until he found a toxic but effective cure for syphilis--a cure that continued to be used until another accidental discovery in 1928: penicillin.

As a Chemical Engineer, I suggest you remind people of the toxic hazard of mercury spills!
You said it once but it deserves an explanation and repeating.

When mercury spills it "fractures" into lots of very tiny droplets. This is particularly bad in that the vapor pressure of mercury is also a function of the radius of curvature of the liquid surface, (not just the temperature)... so small drops have a very much greater ability to make mercury vapors that can be very toxic to humans...... Mercury is "cool" but also dangerous. Suggest that folks watch the videos but NOT start playing around with it . Don't make mercury necklaces or put it in anything that can be easily broken or fall apart,

Just a correction. Thimerosal is not an additive in “many” vaccines. It is still used as a preservative in multi dose vials of flu vaccine. And after looking over the list of ingredients in all FDA approved vaccines, it’s only used as a preservative in those multi dose flu vaccine vials.
Every childhood vaccine is also thimerosal free even the flu shot.
But it’s not even something that’s controversial any more. The amount you’d get in a flu shot (so once a year) is just under 25mcg. That’s equivalent to the elemental mercury that’s in 1 small can of tuna or maybe a couple tuna rolls that you all eat at the sushi restaurant and don’t bat an eye at.
Besides that, thimerosal metabolites are cleared quite quickly from the body and do not bioaccumulate like methylmercury in fish.
